expanded_description: Not all rates of change are equal. Some relationships change quickly, others slowly. Comparing rates of change allows us to understand which quantities are growing or declining faster, make predictions, and choose between options in real-world situations. This section develops skills in analyzing and comparing slopes across different linear functions.

core_concept.principle: The slope $m$ represents the rate of change. When comparing linear functions, a larger absolute value of slope indicates a steeper line and a faster rate of change. Positive slopes indicate increase, negative slopes indicate decrease. To compare rates, we compare their numerical values, paying attention to units and context.
core_concept.explanation: Think of slopes as speeds on different highways. A slope of 60 mph is faster than a slope of 30 mph. A slope of -50 mph (going backward) is a faster rate of change than -20 mph, even though both are negative. The steeper the line, the faster the change, regardless of direction.

image.caption: Figure 4.6.1: Comparing rates of change: steeper slope = faster change.

sections.introduction: The steepness of a line is determined by the absolute value of the slope. Larger absolute value means steeper line.

introduction_image.alt: Lines with slopes 2, 1, 0.5 showing different steepness
introduction_image.caption: Figure 4.6.2: Larger slope magnitude = steeper line.

key_concept.definition: The steepness of a line is determined by the absolute value of its slope, $|m|$. A larger $|m|$ means a steeper line. For example, $|3| > |1|$, so a line with slope 3 is steeper than a line with slope 1. Direction (positive or negative) affects whether the line goes up or down, but not how steep it is.
key_concept.context: When comparing rates, we often care about how fast something is changing, regardless of whether it's increasing or decreasing. A steep negative slope means rapid decrease, which might be just as important as rapid increase.

image.alt: Comparison of slopes 4, 2, -3, -1 showing magnitude determines steepness
image.caption: Figure 4.6.3: |4| > | -3| > |2| > | -1|, so steepness order: 4, -3, 2, -1.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Slope Magnitudes

image.alt: Lines with different slopes
image.caption: Figure 4.6.4: Order lines by steepness.

worked_examples.problem:
Order the lines from steepest to least steep:
a) $m = 5$
b) $m = -3$
c) $m = \frac{1}{2}$
d) $m = -4$
e) $m = 0$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Steepness depends on absolute value of slope. Negative slopes can be steeper than positive ones if their magnitude is larger.

image.caption: Figure 4.6.5: Slope magnitude summary.

sections.section_title: 4.6.2 Comparing Slopes on the Same Graph
sections.introduction: When multiple lines are graphed together, their relative steepness visually shows which has the greater rate of change.

key_concept.definition: On the same coordinate plane, lines with steeper slopes rise or fall more quickly. For a given horizontal distance, a steeper line will have a greater vertical change. This allows direct visual comparison of rates of change.
key_concept.context: This is useful in business to compare profit margins, in science to compare reaction rates, and in everyday life to compare speeds or growth rates.

image.alt: Three lines with slopes 2, 1, -3, showing relative steepness
image.caption: Figure 4.6.7: Line A (slope 2) is steeper than Line B (slope 1). Line C (slope -3) is steeper than both.

worked_examples.title: Visual Comparison of Rates

image.alt: Graph with lines A, B, C, D
image.caption: Figure 4.6.8: Which line has the greatest rate of change?

worked_examples.problem: The graph shows four lines. Which line has the greatest rate of change? Which has the smallest? Order them from greatest to least rate of change.

step_by_step.explanation: Look for line with most vertical change per horizontal unit

image.alt: Line D highlighted as steepest
image.caption: Figure 4.6.9: Line D has greatest rate of change.

step_by_step.calculation: Line A is next steepest (positive), then Line C (negative but less steep than A), then Line B (least steep)

step_by_step.explanation: Rate of change means absolute value of slope

worked_examples.final_answer: Greatest to least rate of change: D, A, C, B
worked_examples.concept_applied: Visually, steeper lines have greater rates of change. Compare by eye, then confirm with values if needed.

worked_examples.title: Confirming Visual Comparison with Calculations

image.alt: Graph with points labeled for slope calculation
image.caption: Figure 4.6.10: Calculate slopes to confirm visual comparison.

worked_examples.problem: For the lines in Figure 4.6.10, calculate the slope of each line and verify the visual comparison.
worked_examples.final_answer: Calculations confirm: D (rate 3) has greatest rate, then A and C (rate 1), then B (rate 0.5).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Visual estimates can be verified by calculating actual slopes.

image.alt: Summary of comparing slopes on same graph
image.caption: Figure 4.6.11: Visual slope comparison summary.

sections.introduction: Sometimes rates are given in different units, requiring conversion before comparison.

introduction_image.alt: Conversion between miles per hour and feet per second
introduction_image.caption: Figure 4.6.12: Comparing rates requires same units.

key_concept.definition: To compare rates of change, they must be in the same units. Convert rates using unit conversion factors so that both numerator and denominator units match. Only then can numerical values be meaningfully compared.
key_concept.context: Real-world rates come in many units: miles per hour vs feet per second, dollars per pound vs cents per ounce, etc. Direct comparison without conversion leads to errors.

image.alt: Conversion example: 60 mph = 88 ft/s
image.caption: Figure 4.6.13: Converting rates to common units.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Speeds in Different Units

image.alt: Speed comparison problem
image.caption: Figure 4.6.14: Which is faster?

worked_examples.problem: Which is faster: 60 miles per hour or 80 feet per second? (1 mile = 5280 feet)
worked_examples.final_answer: 60 mph (88 ft/s) is faster than 80 ft/s.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Convert to common units before comparing rates.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Unit Prices

image.alt: Grocery price comparison
image.caption: Figure 4.6.15: Which is cheaper per ounce?

worked_examples.problem: Which is the better deal: a 16-ounce box for $\$4.48$ or a 24-ounce box for $\$6.48$?
worked_examples.final_answer: 24-ounce box at $\$0.27$/oz is cheaper than 16-ounce at $\$0.28$/oz.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Unit prices allow direct comparison of rates with different quantities.

worked_examples.title: Multi-Context Rate Comparison

image.alt: Various rate scenarios
image.caption: Figure 4.6.22: Compare rates in different contexts.

worked_examples.problem:
For each pair, determine which has the greater rate of change:
a) Car X: 120 km in 2 hours; Car Y: 150 km in 3 hours
b) Phone plan A: $\$30$ for 500 minutes; Plan B: $\$45$ for 800 minutes
c) Population A: grows from 10,000 to 12,000 in 5 years; Population B: grows from 15,000 to 18,000 in 6 years

step_by_step.explanation: Plan A: $30/500 = \$0.06$ per minute; Plan B: $45/800 = \$0.05625$ per minute
step_by_step.calculation: $0.05625 < 0.06$, so Plan B has lower rate (cheaper per minute)

step_by_step.explanation: Pop A: $2000/5 = 400$ people/year; Pop B: $3000/6 = 500$ people/year

worked_examples.final_answer:
a) Car X (60 km/h vs 50 km/h)
b) Plan B has lower cost rate ($\$0.05625$/min vs $\$0.06$/min)
c) Population B (500 people/year vs 400 people/year)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Calculate rates consistently (per unit time or per unit quantity) before comparing.

image.alt: Summary of rate comparisons across contexts
image.caption: Figure 4.6.23: Contextual rate comparison summary.

sections.introduction: Rates of change can be given in different forms: equations, tables, graphs, or verbal descriptions. We need to extract slopes for comparison.

key_concept.definition: To compare rates from different representations, first find the slope from each representation: from an equation (coefficient of x), from a table (Δy/Δx), from a graph (rise/run), from a verbal description (identify the rate). Then compare numerical values with attention to units.
key_concept.context: Real-world data comes in many forms. Being able to extract and compare rates regardless of representation is a key skill.

image.alt: Methods for finding slope from each representation
image.caption: Figure 4.6.25: Extracting slope from different representations.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Rates from Different Representations

image.alt: Rate given in different forms
image.caption: Figure 4.6.26: Which has greatest rate?

worked_examples.problem:
Compare the rates of change from these representations:
a) Equation: $y = 3x - 2$
b) Table: (1,4), (3,10), (5,16)
c) Graph: line through (0,1) and (4,9)
d) Verbal: 'increases by 5 for every 2 units increase in x'

step_by_step.calculation: a and b tie for greatest (3), then d (2.5), then c (2)

worked_examples.final_answer: Greatest rate: a and b (both 3), then d (2.5), then c (2).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Extract slope from each representation, then compare numerical values.

image.alt: Summary of extracting rates from different representations
image.caption: Figure 4.6.27: Comparing across representations summary.

sections.section_title: 4.6.6 Real-World Decision Making with Rate Comparisons
sections.introduction: Comparing rates helps us make informed decisions: choosing the faster route, the better value, the faster-growing investment.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 4.6.28: Using rate comparisons for decisions.

key_concept.definition: When comparing options, identify what rate matters in context. For speed, higher rate is better. For cost, lower rate is better. For growth, higher rate is better (if positive) or lower rate (if negative, like debt). Context determines whether we want the larger or smaller slope.
key_concept.context: Real-world decisions often involve trade-offs. Understanding rates helps quantify those trade-offs and make data-driven choices.

image.alt: Graph showing two options with different slopes
image.caption: Figure 4.6.29: Which option is better depends on context.

worked_examples.title: Choosing the Better Deal

image.alt: Two pricing options
image.caption: Figure 4.6.30: Which subscription is better?

worked_examples.problem:
A streaming service offers two plans:
Plan 1: $\$10$ per month, no annual fee
Plan 2: $\$8$ per month plus $\$24$ annual fee
a) Write cost functions for each plan.
b) Compare the rates (slopes).
c) Which plan is better for 1 year? For 3 years?

step_by_step.calculation: Plan 2 has lower monthly rate (cheaper per month)
Plan 2 is cheaper for longer than 1 year

worked_examples.final_answer:
a) $C_1(m)=10m$, $C_2(m)=8m+24$
b) Plan 2 has lower monthly rate (8 < 10)
c) Equal at 1 year; Plan 2 better for 3 years ($\$312$ vs $\$360$)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Lower slope means cheaper per month, but fixed cost affects total. Compare total cost, not just rates.

worked_examples.title: Choosing the Faster Route

image.alt: Two routes with different speeds
image.caption: Figure 4.6.31: Which route is faster?

worked_examples.problem:
Route A: 120 miles at 60 mph
Route B: 150 miles at 75 mph
Which route takes less time?
worked_examples.final_answer: Both routes take the same time (2 hours). Higher speed compensates for longer distance.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Rate (speed) alone doesn't determine total outcome; distance also matters. Compare total time, not just rates.

image.alt: Summary of using rate comparisons for decisions
image.caption: Figure 4.6.32: Decision-making with rates summary.

sections.section_title: 4.6.7 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when comparing rates of change. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: Comparing rates without converting to common units.
characteristics: Comparing 60 mph to 80 ft/s without conversion
Comparing $\$0.28$/oz to $\$4.48$/16oz (already unit price vs total)
classifications.behavior: Invalid comparisons leading to wrong conclusions.

image.alt: Incorrect direct comparison vs correct after conversion
image.caption: Figure 4.6.33: Error - ignoring units.

examples.process: Error: Saying 80 ft/s is faster than 60 mph without converting
examples.explanation: Correct: Convert 60 mph = 88 ft/s, so 60 mph is faster

classifications.value: Thinking positive slopes are always steeper than negative ones.
characteristics: Assuming slope 2 is steeper than slope -5
Not using absolute value for steepness comparison

image.alt: Slope -5 is steeper than slope 2
image.caption: Figure 4.6.34: Error - ignoring absolute value.

examples.process: Error: Saying slope 3 is steeper than slope -4

classifications.value: Choosing based on slope alone when intercepts matter.
characteristics: Choosing lower monthly rate without considering fixed costs
Not comparing total cost at relevant quantity

image.alt: Two lines with different slopes and intercepts
image.caption: Figure 4.6.35: Error - ignoring intercepts.

examples.process: Error: Choosing Plan B (lower slope) for short term without checking intercept
examples.explanation: Correct: Compare total cost at your specific usage

worked_examples.title: Correcting Rate Comparison Errors

image.alt: Student's incorrect comparison
image.caption: Figure 4.6.36: Find and correct errors.

worked_examples.problem: A student says: 'Slope 5 is steeper than slope -7, and 60 mph is faster than 90 ft/s.' Identify and correct the errors.

step_by_step.explanation: Convert 60 mph to ft/s: 60 mph = 88 ft/s
step_by_step.calculation: 88 ft/s vs 90 ft/s → 90 > 88, so 90 ft/s is faster

worked_examples.final_answer: Correct: -7 is steeper than 5; 90 ft/s is faster than 60 mph.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Use absolute value for steepness; convert units before comparing rates.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills in comparing rates of change to a variety of problems.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set

image.alt: Multiple practice problems
image.caption: Figure 4.6.38: Practice problems.

worked_examples.problem:
1) Order from steepest to least steep: $m=4$, $m=-2$, $m=\frac{1}{2}$, $m=-5$, $m=0$
2) Which is faster: 55 mph or 80 ft/s? (1 mile = 5280 ft)
3) Compare unit prices: 12 oz for $\$3.48$ or 18 oz for $\$5.04$?
4) Two savings plans: Plan A: $y = 200x + 1000$, Plan B: $y = 150x + 1500$, where x = years. Which has higher monthly rate? Which has more after 5 years?
5) From table: (1,3), (4,15) and from graph: through (0,2) and (3,11). Which has greater slope?

step_by_step.explanation: Plan A slope = 200, Plan B slope = 150, so Plan A has higher monthly rate

step_by_step.calculation: From graph: (0,2) to (3,11): $m = \frac{11-2}{3-0} = \frac{9}{3} = 3$; Table slope (4) > graph slope (3)

worked_examples.final_answer:
1) $-5$, $4$, $-2$, $\frac{1}{2}$, $0$
2) 55 mph (80.67 ft/s) is faster
3) 18 oz at $\$0.28$/oz is better
4) Plan A has higher rate; Plan A has more after 5 years ($\$3000$ vs $\$2250$)
5) Table slope (4) > graph slope (3)
worked_examples.concept_applied: Practice comparing rates across different representations and contexts.

summary: Comparing rates of change means comparing slopes of linear functions. The steepness of a line is determined by the absolute value of the slope $|m|$—larger absolute value means steeper line and faster rate of change. When comparing slopes on the same graph, steeper lines have greater rates. When rates are given in different units, convert to common units before comparing. Rates can be extracted from equations, tables, graphs, and verbal descriptions—always find the numerical slope value for comparison. Context matters: for speed, higher rate is better; for cost, lower rate is better; for growth, higher rate is better (positive) or lower rate for decline. Intercepts also matter when comparing total amounts over time. Understanding rate comparisons enables informed decision-making in real-world situations involving speed, cost, growth, and other changing quantities.
